quoteFirst: On the Sunday night after you left, or rather on the Monday morning at
quoteLast: , Mary was taken _very ill_. English cholera. She was sinking so fast, and the sickness was so exceedingly alarming, that it evidently would not do to wait for Elliotson. I caused everything to be done that we had naturally often thought of, in a lonely house so full of children, and fell back upon the old remedy; though the difficulty of giving even it was rendered very great by the frightful sickness.
title: The Letters of Charles Dickens. Vol. 1, 1833-1856
author: Dickens, Charles, 1812-1870; Dickens, Mamie, 1838-1896 [Editor]; Hogarth, Georgina, 1827-1917 [Editor]

quoteFirst: By
quoteLast: , P. M., on Friday, the 23d, arrangements for the funeral ceremonies in the rotunda were all completed and the chairs and sofas labelled to designate for whom they were reserved. The positions of the floral offerings were changed, and now nothing remained upon the casket save a few branches of palm.

quoteFirst: Three handsome brass guns were carried off, the iron guns were spiked, and the magazines destroyed.  The steamer then taking the _Royalist_ and gunboats in tow, passed two other batteries and anchored half-a-mile below the city, when all hands went to dinner.  At
quoteLast: the expedition was again in motion, working up against an ebb tide of three knots.  As the _Phlegethon_ opened round the point, the city battery and hill forts mounting 18 guns, commenced firing, and two men were killed and several wounded on board the _Phlegethon_.
title:
How Britannia Came to Rule the Waves
Updated to 1900
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteFirst: Operations opened with digging with the entrenching tool--each man to make cover for himself. By 8 p.m. this stage had been reached, so tea and shovels were issued. At 9 p.m. serious digging began, the shelters being converted into trenches, and this continued till
quoteLast: Coffee was then served, and work went on till dawn, which provided an opportunity to practise standing-to. A rest followed, but after breakfast work was again resumed.

quoteFirst: He thought he heard Helen giggle softly. “My _dear_ Dr. Latham! Oh!”—then, with a sudden change of manner, that was one of her most bewildering traits, an instant change this time from the hysterical to the commonplace—“You will have lunch with me to-morrow—
quoteLast: .” It was not a question, but simply an announcement.

quoteFirst: The English flagship was delivered from the attack of her powerful antagonist by the "Trinidad" drifting clear of her. By this time Fremantle was attacking her with the "Neptune," supported by the "Colossus." At
quoteLast: a third ship joined in the close attack on the towering "Trinidad," which every captain who got anywhere near her was anxious to make his prize. This new ally was the battleship "Africa.

quoteLast: we sat down to lunch _en famille_ as usual."

quoteFirst: Waited on Captain Flinders who desired me to send our main keel on board in order to be repaired and at the same time he informed me that he would be on board in the morning and move the Lady Nelson for the examination of the bay. At daylight sent our keel on board and at half-past 6 Captain Flinders came on board, immediately weighed and made all sail to the south-east part of the bay. At
quoteLast: 0 entered a large branch or arm of the bay or river following Captain Flinders in his boat steering east and east-south-east we anchored per order of Captain Flinders and he continued on in his boat.* (* Flinders went two miles up the river, landed, and took a set of angles here.

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: , the slaves arrived. One was a black girl about twelve years old, and she was dressed in boy’s clothes; the other, the Abyssinian, a young woman, was veiled from head to foot in the Egyptian manner. The Turkish servants seemed to consider female slaves as a necessary part of a great man’s retinue: they spoke of it as a matter of course.
